Susan Davis – behind the music and special events at FOA for 23 years

By DIANNE RUSSELL

Photos by Mary Hurlbut

If you’ve enjoyed the incredible concert series at Festival of the Arts (FOA), attended Family Day or been dazzled by the Festival Runway Fashion Show, you have Director of Special Events Susan Davis to thank. From award-winning musicians to Le PeTiT CiRqUe, during her 23-year career at FOA, Davis has delivered the best in music and magical happenings to attendees.

Although she recently retired, Davis is still a presence at the Festival of Arts. “I booked the music for this summer, so I’m hanging out and saying hello to the musicians. I’ve dealt with so many of the bands for years,” she said. The number of musicians she schedules per summer is mind-boggling. During a Festival season – 55 nights with two performances a day on weekends – she books 60-70 concerts.

Click on photo for a larger image

Susan Davis

However, Davis – fueled by her passion for music and art – had an ulterior motive behind her creation of fabulous entertainment.

When she started as director of events, “One of my goals was to bring some energy to the Festival of Arts grounds. My other goal was to bring in first-time visitors, who might come for the music, but while here they are exposed to all the other great things that the Festival is, namely our extraordinary art exhibit and our world-famous Pageant of the Masters.”

Davis is well-versed in art history. She grew up on Long Island and graduated from Emmanuel College in Boston with a BA in Art History.

“I was going to college in Boston in the early ‘70s,” she said. “A lot was happening; it was the time of the anti-war protests and hippie life and being in a college town was wild fun.”

Before moving to Southern California, Davis lived in New York, Boston, Chicago, Houston and Detroit.

“When I arrived here in Laguna, I was a newly single mom with two daughters,” she said.

Fate leads Davis to the Festival of Arts

A happenstance meeting sent her in the direction of the FOA.

“I met the director of guest services, who learned I was looking for a job in my field,” she explained. “One thing led to another, and I took a job in the Pageant Box Office selling Pageant tickets to get a ‘foot in the door.’ Through a series of opportunities, I was made director of special events and member services.”

That was in 2001 and over the next 23 years, she developed a summer concert series that brings world-class musicians to their stage. Davis considers the concert series her favorite accomplishment while at FOA.

Click on photo for a larger image

Davis on the night of a Santana tribute band

“The success of the evening music performances didn’t happen overnight. It grew over years,” Davis said. “The level of musicians also grew with time and many nights we have grammy-winning performers on our stage.

“With the encouragement of the Festival’s board of directors, things began to develop. We eventually got a world-class sound system with the guidance of Production Manager Sid Greenbaum. We also have a wonderful performance stage that we’ve had for the past seven years.”

Considering the number of musicians Davis has booked over the years, it’s surprising there’ve only been a few snafus – once when a band didn’t show up, she called pianist Scott Wilkie (a frequent wonderful FOA performer) who cut a Home Depot visit short and speeded over to play.

“Pianist Tom Zink was stung by a bee before a performance. He was quickly treated, came back and finished his entire performance,” she said. “And Grammy Award singer Melissa Manchester broke her leg three days before the FOA Annual Gala, yet she appeared anyway.” That proves the adage – “the show must go on.”

Click on photo for a larger image

It all began in the Box Office

One of the most popular Festival events is the Runway Fashion Show – now in its 15th year – which was also Davis’ idea. “Dan Duling, the scriptwriter for the Pageant, suggested I go see a theater production in L.A. by the “99 Cent Production Company,” she explained. “Everything they did, the sets and costumes, were all made from things from the 99 Cents Store. I said to Festival board member Pat Kollenda, who attended the performance with me, ‘Exhibiting Festival artists can do this but instead of using 99 Cents Store items, we could use recycled materials, make a runway competition out of it’ and that’s how the Festival Runway Fashion Show was born.”

Fair Game

By TOM JOHNSON

Kids return to school, the Fire Association endorses Hallie Jones for City Council and Village Laguna plans candidates’ forum

This Thursday the kids head back to school.

I’ll be honest, as a kid I hated school. When summer started coming to a close I’d begin getting depressed. The night before that first day back, which was usually the Tuesday following Labor Day, I’d lie in bed, toss and turn all night, and think, “How far off is Christmas vacation?”

Back then it seemed so far in the future that I’d think, “Well, we have a three-day weekend coming up with Columbus Day, then Veterans Day and finally in November we get four days for Thanksgiving. I can make this.”

It somehow got me through. But barely.

At the time, I would guess I had some level of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivty Disorder, today simply called ADHD. Back then, instead of some type of treatment, you’d have your parents yelling at you, “I know you can do better…you just have to apply yourself!” It really wasn’t their problem…they didn’t know. Restrictions and punishment usually followed.

Go figure, heck, I’d hardly pay attention to even what they had to say.

Actually, in the 1950s and 1960s, ADHD was referred to as “Minimal Brain Dysfunction Syndrome.” That seemed right to me…“minimal brain!”

Symptoms of ADHD were just beginning to be diagnosed and wouldn’t become mainstream for another decade or two.

I remember back then being sent to a church counseling session one weekend in the next town over, probably around my early teens. Kids sat in a circle and shared their “failures” or “shortcomings” in life.

A girl around me said something like, “I ran away from home, drank and did drugs, slept around…and I hate my parents.” Yikes!

A teenage guy talked about nearly murdering someone in a fight, as a cigarette dangled from his lips.

The hour or so left an impression…or maybe better said, “A scar.”

When the discussion came around to me, I had nothing to add. I cowered and said, “I once talked back to my folks.”

I realized I was a woose, in the worst way!

The kid up for attempted murder basically looked at me thinking, “Who is this clown?” I just kept my head down at all costs avoiding eye contact, thinking he’d probably want to take me out at the bike racks after the meeting.

I went home and begged my folks to never, ever send me back. In the moment, I promised I’d do better.

Still, my efforts at school and at home didn’t change. The folks would try again, saying something to the effect of, “We know you’re as smart or smarter than your brother, you just have to try,” they pleaded.

My response would be something like, “What about better looking than him?”

Anyway, it was always a struggle.

My senior year I was accepted to San Diego State, with one caveat. First, you have to remember, back in the early ‘70s, you didn’t need an SAT score of 1,100+. Times have changed! I chose it because it was the furthest place from home without paying out-of-state tuition.

Anyway, the caveat was I needed a 3.5 GPA my final semester. With my back against the wall…I pulled a 4.0. And never looked back.

Still, every year as the new school year approaches, I feel bad for the kids today for what lies ahead. Most will be fine…they love it and get excited to learn new things, meet their teachers and make friends.

But, for those like me, please, handle them with care…they’ll get there eventually…I promise.

BTW, Christmas vacation starts on December 20…only 122 days or so away. You can make it!

The Laguna Beach Firefighters Association, International Association of Firefighters Local 3684 has endorsed Hallie Jones for City Council, according to Association President Tom Padden.

“Candidates all talk a good game around ‘public safety’ while campaigning for office, but Hallie Jones is the ‘real deal,’ with a substantial track record of helping the Fire Department mitigate our extreme wildfire hazard throughout Laguna Beach,” Padden noted.

“During her 10 years as Executive Director of the Laguna Canyon Foundation, Hallie and her colleagues partnered with the Fire Department to develop and implement what the former Executive Director of the California Coastal Commission described as the most environmentally sensitive fuel modification program they had ever seen, worthy of being used as a model throughout California.

“Having worked closely with her for many years, Laguna Beach firefighters know that Hallie is a strong supporter of fire safety and will be an effective advocate on Council for measures needed to protect this community,” Padden added.

• • •

Attend the meeting to learn about the candidates’ visions for the future of Laguna Beach. If you are not able to be there in person, the forum will be available on channel 852.

All are welcome.

Dennis’ Local Almanac

By DENNIS McTIGHE

Rocking and rolling

Yet another weekend washout in the already soggy Northeast and of course the weather will improve on Monday when all the 9 to 5ers return to work. By this time, I’d be movin’ – in the meantime, here in our little piece of Paradise, it was sunny and 78 degrees with inviting ocean temps in the low 70s.

Hurricane Ernesto is finally out of the picture as it races to the NE at 22 mph after a direct hit on Bermuda, the 13th time since 1871 that’s happened. Bermuda is such a small target, a mere 21 miles long and 1.5 miles wide, so there have been more near misses than there have been direct hits. The peak season is rapidly approaching, and September 10 marks the pinnacle date of possible maximum potential for development of tropical systems.

Here at 9 p.m. on Sunday, it looked like things were going to be fairly quiet for at least the upcoming week, which is a good thing. Stronger than normal upper-level shear winds are stumping upward. They are moving warm unstable air into the higher reaches of the atmosphere as the expansive dust plume from the Sahara is still pretty much running the show. The surrounding surface ocean temps are being moderated into slightly cooler temps as radiation from the sun is not running at full strength – so it’s a more hostile environment down there as we enter the fourth week of August.

Normally by late August, the giant dust cloud from the Sahara has dissipated somewhat and is pretty much gone by early September. But this year has seen stronger than normal easterly winds which is actually a good thing. The NOAA and the NHC are still calling for a record number of tropical systems in the Atlantic and a record low number of tropical systems in the Eastern Pacific but there have been eight systems so far in the EPAC with two more waiting in the wings. As a result, it’s not acting like a normal La Niña at all up to this point. Local ocean temps were really up on Sunday evening with 73-74 degrees in town and 77 in San Clemente.

Last week’s 4.4 shaker really rattled nerves around here. The epicenter was right under South Pasadena, and it seemed quite a bit stronger because the quake – at four miles deep – was so shallow. Seismically, it’s been pretty quiet as of late, so we were due. Over the decades I’ve been a part of some real shakers. In July 1952, there was a 7.5 up by Bakersfield. I was almost 5, but I remember all the violent shaking that shattered a couple of the windows in my folks’ little house in Hollywood where I was born. I was rudely awakened and shaken out of bed at 6 a.m. on February 9, 1971, by the 6.6 rock ‘n’ roller in Sylmar. That one lasted a whole minute, but it felt like an hour.

At 2:24 a.m. on July 9, 1986, there was a 6.0 at 2:20 a.m. at Windy Point near Palm Springs that woke me up quick, as it was a shallow five miles deep. Five days later at 7 a.m. a 5.5 shaker happened a few miles off Oceanside. I was riding my bike through town when the shaking started and watched that big front window at the Fingerhut Gallery get wrenched out, falling into a hundred pieces on the sidewalk on the corner of PCH and Forest Avenue. On October 1, 1987, a 6.0 struck near Whittier, about 40 miles up the road at 4 a.m., which rudely shook me out of my deep slumber. Seems like these shakers always happen way too early in the morning.

More on shakers next time, ALOHA!

LOCA hits a home run with Angels at Boys & Girls Club

LOCA Arts Education partnered with the Angels Baseball Foundation in presenting a children’s art workshop at Boys & Girls Club in Laguna Beach recently.

Click on photo for a larger image

Photos by Mike Tauber

(L-R) President of Angels Baseball John Carpino and LOCA representative Rich Fair

John Carpino, president of Angels Baseball came to meet the kids, answer questions and relive memories of the club. “My three kids came here, and I was a basketball coach here – this is a real special place,” he said. He mingled among LOCA representatives Rich Fair, KC Mechling and Mike Tauber, and LOCA art teachers Sherry Bullard, Allison Keefe, Lisa Rainey and Brittney Silva. Staff from Boys & Girls Club, on hand to support the capacity crowd included Cody Howell, Mar Stash and Steve Sliwoski who said, “It’s always great when LOCA is teaching here, they are fabulous as always, but bringing in the Angels brought this to the next level!”

Click on photo for a larger image

Base bowling

Kids migrated between three workstations, each with an activity custom designed by LOCA for the event. One was a printmaking station, where kids dipped bats, balls and cleats in paint and created abstract designs on watercolor paper. “We did a lot of out-of-the-box thinking as we developed the projects,” said Allison Keefe. “It shows how you can use found objects in the creation of art.” Another project nicknamed “base bowling” involved one kid tossing a paint-dipped ball across a giant floor canvas, and another kid catching it. “We were lucky to have lots of space to do this,” said Lisa Rainey, “it was very hands-on, active, playful and messy!” she said. A student named Cody, on his fourth roll, said “I want to go again,” as the game erupted in laughter and cheers for each other. The Jackson Pollack-style finished art was disassembled, and each child took home a signed section.

Click on photo for a larger image

A young attendee designs a “Thank You” card to be sent to Angels Baseball

The third project was the creation of thank you notes to be sent to Angels Baseball. Kids learned how to draw the iconic “A” logo, along with a baseball diamond and sports equipment. “Thank you notes are very important,” said student Penelope. The event concluded with a gathering of the kids singing happy birthday, on camera, to Arte Moreno, owner of the Los Angeles Angels. Hats and jerseys featuring Mike Trout #27, were distributed to each child, along with tickets to an upcoming game.

Click on photo for a larger image

“Thank You” cards

“One of the pillars of the Angels Baseball Foundation is to nurture the artistic and creative potential of kids through art and education. We are excited to partner with these great organizations to make a positive impact in the community,” said Dennis Kuhl, president of the Angels Baseball Foundation.

For more information about the Angels Baseball Foundation, visit www.angels.com/community.

To join LOCA membership or subscribe to the eNewsletter, visit www.locaarts.org/.

A glimpse at Crystal Cove in Summer

Crystal Cove Conservancy has kicked off the 2024 summer season with extensive programming for all ages that span from the beach to the trails. Visitors will be delighted to see a combination of new and returning programs at Crystal Cove State Park, as well as extended dates for one of the Conservancy’s most popular programs – “The Great Plein Air Art Experience,” which will now run through October.

“Summertime at Crystal Cove is magical – and our programs team has been working all year to create new opportunities for folks to explore the park and to reimagine old favorites,” said Crystal Cove Conservancy President & CEO Kate Wheeler. “Our team has been testing new ideas like science hikes and rethinking and expanding classics like the Historic District Walking Tours and movies on the beach to create a menu of programs to help parkgoers deepen their connection with the park and become part of protecting it.”

From hands-on explorations of history and nature to art classes and conservation stewardship, there is something for everyone to explore during the summer at Crystal Cove.

Click on photo for a larger image

Sign up to spend a relaxing day capturing the beauty of the Cove on canvas with Crystal Cove plein air artist, Debbie Morines

–The Great Plein Air Art Experience every Monday and Wednesday through October, except September 2 from 9 a.m.-2 p.m. Registration is required. Celebrate more than 100 years of plein air art at Crystal Cove State Park and spend a relaxing day capturing the beauty of the Cove on canvas with Crystal Cove plein air artist, Debbie Morines. During these four-hour classes, you’ll take part in living history while learning the step-by-step process of creating your very own plein air painting from beginning to end. Each class will have a break for lunch, but lunch is not provided. Classes are for ages 18 and up. Register here.

–Junior Ranger Programs, Tuesday and Thursday mornings, through August 29 from 10-11 a.m. Join a Park Ranger for a fun introduction to the animals and plants of Crystal Cove State Park in their weekly Junior Ranger programs. This children’s nature program is a favorite in State Parks and allows kids to earn a badge, stamps, a poster, or a patch. Each Tuesday they will focus on tidepools and on Thursdays they will learn about sharks. Meet at the Berns Amphitheater (PCH inland at stoplight School-State Park, follow signs towards the Campground.) $15 day use fee. No program on July 4.

LAM unveils new exhibition

On August 17, Laguna Art Museum (LAM) unveiled an exhibition showcasing nearly 50 newly acquired artworks. This collection marks a significant expansion of the museum’s permanent collection, focusing on pieces by influential California artists, works exploring the nexus of art and nature, and those by a diverse range of California-based artists with a particular effort to increase representation of women. Additionally, the exhibition aims to broaden contemporary themes by featuring artworks created after the year 2000.

The artworks, spanning over a century of creation, encompass a diverse array of mediums including sculpture, mixed media, film, painting and large-format color photography. Notably, a series of John Humble’s photographs titled Sunday Morning will be highlighted as a standalone mini-exhibition.

Click on photo for a larger image

Photos courtesy of LAM

Patrick Wilson, “Inside Space,” 2020, promised gift of Bob and Ann Myers

More than simply displaying these new acquisitions, the exhibition serves as a gesture of gratitude to the generous individuals who donated these artworks to the Laguna Art Museum. Among the artists featured are Jay McCafferty, Woods Davy, Roger Kuntz, Astrid Preston, Millard Owen Sheets, Craig Stecyk and newcomers to the collection such as Mark Bennett, Sergei Bongart, Carole Caroompas, Jedediah Caesar, Rosson Crow, Fannie Eliza Duvall, John Frost, Jimi Gleason, Jennifer Gunlock, Grace Carpenter Hudson, Tom Lamb, Robert Landry, Malerie Marder, Carter Mull, Evan Nesbit, Deborah Oropallo, Phil Paradise, Rozeal, Richard Roth, Heidi Schwegler, Robert Standish, Jennifer West and Patrick Wilson.

John Humble’s Sunday Afternoon series features images of industrial areas near the Port of Los Angeles. He took these photos when there were no cars, trucks, or work activities, revealing scenes that are remarkably quiet. Humble is interested in photographing these locations because they show what large parts of Los Angeles look like. These are places rarely visited or experienced by most people, and even less seen when businesses are closed for the weekend.

Humble used a large format film camera to create detailed color photographs. He frequently set up his camera in the middle of abandoned streets, draped a black curtain over his head to block out light and adjusted the tripod to handle uneven surfaces, ensuring he captured the perfect shot. The stillness of these images helps viewers notice hyper-realistic and intricate details in the buildings and surroundings that are usually missed.

Humble is a distinguished photographer who has made Los Angeles his home since 1974. His career has been shaped by his military service in Vietnam, his tenure as a photojournalist at the Washington Post and his advanced studies at the San Francisco Art Institute. His work is in the collection of institutions around the world, and he has exhibited in many prestigious museums including the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Library of Congress, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and The J. Paul Getty Museum where he had a solo exhibition in 2007.

Matthew Curry – August 23

–Friday, Aug. 23, 8 p.m.

Matthew Curry

The Sky and Ocean Aren’t the Only Way to See Inspiring Blues in Laguna in 2024

If you’re a fan of blues rock, you need to check out Matthew Curry. This Illinois-based singer/songwriter is renowned for his incredible guitar-playing abilities, which have earned him opening touring slots with some of the biggest names in the business, including The Doobie Brothers, Peter Frampton and Steve Miller Band. He’s played at some of the most prestigious venues and festivals in the country, and his performances never disappoint. Curry’s music appeals to a broad audience, with fans traveling from far and wide to see him live. Drawing from personal inspirations, his songs incorporate elements of rock, blues, southern rock and old school country, creating a sound that is uniquely his own. So, if you’re looking for an unforgettable live music experience, make sure to catch Curry in action.

Eric Henderson – August 25

–Sunday, Aug. 25

Summer Concert Series, every other Sunday

Step into the world of musical enchantment with a LBCAC Summer Concert Series, featuring the internationally acclaimed Concert Guitarist Eric Henderson and his extraordinary quartet, Malaga.

Witness the magic as Curtis Mathewson and Richard Bredice mesmerize on electric guitar, Henderson serenades on Spanish guitar, Jimmy Perez sets the rhythm on bass and Frank Cotinola brings beats to life on drums.

Experience the soulful resonance of the guitar in the intimate setting of OC’s premier listening room, where every note is a symphony of emotions. Join this unforgettable evening filled with Spanish classical guitar masterpieces by Henderson and a captivating blend of new tunes and timeless classics like “Little Wing” and “Paint It Black.” Embrace the harmonious fusion of talent and passion at LBCAC’s Summer Concert Series.

Brian Templeton and Kid Ramos – September 6

–Friday, Sept. 6, 8 p.m.

Brian Templeton and Kid Ramos

The sky and ocean aren’t the only way to see inspiring blues in Laguna in 2024.

The Laguna Beach Cultural Arts Center has stepped up to preserve one of America’s most powerful and influential art forms, by providing a memorable OC haven for national touring blues legends.

The LBCAC offers its intimate listening room, stellar acoustics, state-of-the-art sound system and a host town recognized as one of the nation’s leading arts-centric resort destinations.

Kid Ramos is an American electric blues and blues rock guitarist, singer and songwriter. Ramos has released four solo albums since 1995 on Black Top and Evidence Records. He joined the James Harman’s band in 1980 and stayed playing his guitar until 1988, when he briefly helped with Roomful of Blues. In 2009, Ramos backed Bobby Jones at the Notodden Blues Festival. In 1999, 2000 and 2001, WC Handy nominated him for Best Blues Record of the Year, Best Blues Guitarist, Best Song Winner 2001, and recipient of the 2014 OC music Lifetime Achievement Award.

Brian Templeton is a vocalist, songwriter and harmonica player. Templeton has blues music in his DNA, as they say. He is probably best known for his work with The Radio Kings, and plying his trade with The Delta Generators who he still plays the harmonica with and provides lead vocals. Recently, he joined forces to form another band with a more eclectic take of the blues music genre. The band is called The Proven Ones and includes Kid Ramos on guitar, Jimi Bott on drums, Willie J Campbell on bass and Anthony Geraci on keyboards.

For tickets, click here.

Orange County students honored at FOA Junior Art Awards

By MARRIE STONE

Photos by Jeff Rovner

This story is a part of our Arts section. For more arts stories as well as our arts calendars, visit www.stunewslaguna.com/arts.

Never underestimate the impact adult recognition makes in a child’s life. For longtime Festival of Arts (FOA) exhibitor Kirsten Whalen, that moment arrived in kindergarten when her artwork received an honorable mention and appeared in the local newspaper. “I’ll never forget it,” she said. “When anybody tells you you’ve done something unique and interesting and valuable, it sticks in your head. You take it forward. It’s so meaningful.”

Whalen’s experience came full circle this year when she served as one of the final judges of the FOA’s 77th Annual Junior Art Awards. “We have to honor students’ creative work,” she said. “It’s so exciting for the kids and inspiring [for the rest of us].”

Click on photo for a larger image

Kirsten Whalen (far right), of the FOA Foundation, presented the awards alongside fellow judge Nancy Darnall and sponsor Mark Porterfield. Kindergartner Matilda Martinez won the Director’s Award and the Kindergarten Postcard Award for “Cute Fury Yeti.”

The FOA Junior Art Exhibition is the culmination of a process that begins when the Orange County Department of Education solicits art submissions from all Orange County schools for the annual OCArts4All program. This year, the county received 1,500 submissions from 99 schools. A team of FOA jurors selected more than 300 of these submissions to showcase at the Junior Art Exhibit throughout the summer. Last Sunday, the Festival held their annual awards ceremony, honoring students at every grade level and across several mediums, ultimately awarding 69 medals to young artists.

Click on photo for a larger image

The 2024 Junior Art Exhibit Award winners, jurors, presenters, supporters and educators gathered to celebrate on Sunday, Aug. 11

But the picture of arts education isn’t entirely rosy, highlighting the need for programs like this. Whalen pointed to falling submission rates, which have been dropping over the past decade. Even prior to the pandemic, she witnessed a decline. “We used to have four rooms of tables piled high with artwork. It was down to two before COVID, and it’s shrunk dramatically since. That’s really disturbing to me,” she said.

Submissions dipped to an all-time low in 2021 (down to only 500). The program regained some momentum in 2022 and held steady from last year, but Whalen hopes for significant improvement. Some educators point to an increased emphasis on STEM programming, and a hyper-focus on test scores. Whalen notes the overwhelming workloads burdening teachers and some districts’ deemphasis on the arts. Laguna, she said, is extremely fortunate in its rich arts education program. Not all Orange County schools can compete.

Whatever the cause, all this adds up to the increasing importance and relevance of programming like the FOA’s Junior Art Exhibition and the Junior Art Awards.

Click on photo for a larger image

Family, friends and teachers gathered at the FOA grounds last Sunday to celebrate their students’ accomplishments

Wendy Wu, an arts teacher in the La Habra City School District, was honored this year for her outstanding contributions to elementary arts education. After California voters passed Proposition 28 in 2022, and money was directed to local schools to fund arts education, Wu was finally offered a full-time position with benefits. Today she’s the only arts teacher for that district, teaching eight classes per day, grades TK (transitional kindergarten) through 6th, across six different Title 1 schools.

“The district didn’t have a budget for elementary arts education,” Wu said, noting she’s been teaching part-time for years. “Students didn’t have exposure to art, especially the visual arts. Once I started, they were so excited. Many of them had no experience using a brush, paint or other basic supplies. They were just grateful I was there, and happy to be in an environment that was so open. Everything was new to them.”

Click on photo for a larger image

Arts Educator Wendy Wu appearing with award-winning work by 2nd grader Harvey Mayhall

Wu wheels her art cart from classroom to classroom, estimating she teaches between 1,800 and 2,400 students across the various grade levels and half-dozen schools. In some classrooms, she has less than 20 minutes to teach a lesson. Nonetheless, 17 of Wu’s students were chosen for this year’s show and 6th grader Alan Huizar was selected to have his work showcased at the Samueli Theater at the Segerstrom Center for the Arts this spring.

LAM presents the Directors Circle Dinner and Awards Night on September 26

Laguna Art Museum (LAM) has announced the Directors Circle Dinner and Awards Night, an annual event that brings together an exclusive group of museum members whose philanthropic support allows the museum’s mission to flourish. This year’s event will take place on Thursday, Sept. 26 at Crystal Cove State Park, offering an evening of gratitude, exquisite dining and celebration.

The evening will commence with a cocktail reception followed by dinner overlooking the California coast. During the evening, the museum will present the Anna Hills Award to Betsy and Gary Jenkins for their exceptional generosity towards Laguna Art Museum.

Click on photo for a larger image

Courtesy of LAM

Betsy and Gary Jenkins, recipients of the Anna Hills Award

The Anna Hills Award is named after the brilliant early 20th century landscape and seascape painter, a founding member of Laguna Art Museum and Laguna Beach community leader, Anna Hills. This award honors those who have gone above and beyond in their service to the institution. Gary and Betsy Jenkins have been incredibly generous supporters of the museum – going well beyond the financial support they provide. They are passionate about the museum’s place in Laguna as the first and arguably the most important arts organization in a town, which has been inextricably connected to the arts from even before the city’s founding.

They are among the first to enthusiastically support the activities and programming the museum brings to the community. For those who have the pleasure of visiting their home, you’ll see a wonderful collection of artworks that were bought in contribution to the museum. In addition to championing the mission of the museum, they contribute to the cultural life in Laguna by serving at many organizations throughout the city.

“Laguna Art Museum is the crown jewel in Laguna’s long and lustrous history as an art colony,” said Betsy Jenkins. “Founded in 1918 by artists, the museum is still today beloved and supported by artists everywhere as well as the general public. Gary and I first joined as members in 1980 and are proud to have remained passionate advocates for the museum throughout the decades. We are so very honored to be chosen as recipients of the Anna Hills Award.”

The Directors Circle is comprised of a diverse group of members from various backgrounds such as philanthropy, filmmaking, business, environmental and community development. They all share a profound love for the museum and are instrumental in the success of the museum. Last year, the Directors Circle enabled the museum to serve 4,000 Title 1 students, host history-making exhibitions and offer four times the number of programs for the community.

The Directors Circle Dinner and Awards Night is an annual event that brings together the museum members whose philanthropic support allows the museum’s mission to flourish. This year’s event will take place on Thursday, Sept. 26, at Crystal Cove’s Historic District, overlooking the dazzling coastline, and offering an evening of gratitude, exquisite dining and celebration. Beyond the annual Dinner and Awards Night, the Directors Circle gathers on several occasions throughout the year to deepen members’ relationships with the arts and with one another. These lively parties are often at private homes with collectors, curators and notable artists.

If you are looking to unite with others who are dedicated to making an impact in our community – while also having a great time – consider joining this unique group. Directors Circle Member engagement impacts and supports the museum in multiple ways, ensuring the mission to enlighten and engage people of all ages with art that embodies the California experience.

Jo Situ Allen, who is being honored as Artist of the Year, has provided visual inspiration for this year’s Directors Circle Dinner and Awards Night. Directors Circle members will receive an artwork designed by Situ Allen specially for the occasion.

Laguna Art Museum is located at 307 Cliff Drive in Laguna Beach, on the corner of Coast Highway and Cliff Drive.

Art-A-Fair: Upcoming offerings at Laguna’s “Festival Without Borders” range from exhibits to workshops, music to puppies

By THERESA KEEGAN

This story is a part of our Arts section. For more arts stories as well as our arts calendars, visit www.stunewslaguna.com/arts.

This summer appreciation and admiration of both artists and visitors are flourishing under the canvas tarps of Art-A-Fair. “It’s changed a lot,” said participating artist Barbara Palmer-Davis. “The artists juried in keep getting better and better. This year is the best.”

Indeed, a walk through the festival reveals an impressive array of booths, with colorful and impressive art in a variety of mediums, from traditional oil and pastels to woodworking, glass, beading and textile. Touted as a “Festival Without Borders” there is also a distinct international perspective. Palmer-Davis, who has been showing at the festival for 30 years, has a booth next to an artist from South Africa.

“I really enjoy talking with him,” she said, adding that conversations extend well beyond artistic techniques and there’s been a deep camaraderie among the artists this summer.

Click on photo for a larger image

Photo by Theresa Keegan

The display areas at this year’s Art-A-Fair festival are opened up and flow into each other. Attendees can drift among the displays of 115 artists from throughout the world.

In addition to the diverse range of artists, the workshops at Art-A-Fair have also been popular this year.

“We had more workshop signups online this year, before we even opened, than we completed last year,” said Emilee Reed, an exhibitor and instructor at Art-A-Fair.

With 19 different instructors, and topics ranging from jewelry making to art pour, watercolors and even gourd making, the diversity of the workshops is appealing. There is at least one, and sometimes two, workshops a day.

Click on photo for a larger image

Courtesy of Laguna Art-A-Fair

Many workshops are held at the central gazebo area of Laguna Art-A-Fair, where passersby can see classes in action

“Even if they (visitors) don’t have workshops on their mind they see it (classes) happening when they visit, and then they want to sign up,” said Reed. “It’s just a fun experience to get to know a little about a particular thing you’re interested in.”

Artist Sandra Morrison, who has been at Art-A-Fair for the past two years and is leading workshops this summer, said the reasons people attend the workshops are as diverse as the attendees.

“Some people just love doing workshops and take all different things because they want to learn and have a good time, and others want to increase their skills,” she said. “I think everybody has different reasons for taking the workshops.”

Click on photo for a larger image

Courtesy of Sandra Morrison

Artist Sandra Morrison (left) is thrilled she can connect with people who visit her booth at Art-A-Fair

Looking at the artwork is also an inspiration to many who visit the summer festivals and some sign up for the workshops after they’re on site, if space is available.

“When someone walks into Art-A-Fair, they walk in and look around and say, ‘Wow!’ I think they are really inspired by everything they see,” said Morrison.

Her workshop on discovering pastels has been well received. “In the workshops we’ve had a lot of happy people who are pleased in what they’re creating.”

And she expects interest in the Festival will remain strong and even increase as the summer winds down. History supports her theory.

“The last three weeks, it really picks up,” she said. “There’s that sense of urgency ‘If I don’t go now, it’s going to go away.’” Sales also pick up as people return for what she calls a “second touch” – an opportunity to revisit something they had seen earlier in the summer but weren’t ready to purchase at the time.

“Art is a crapshoot,” she said. “You just never know when someone will buy something.”

Also, the upcoming special events at Art-A-fair should bring in people from throughout Orange County.

Palmer-Davis can’t wait for the Ohio Trio to come to the festival. Their re-creation of music by The Platters is a favorite for many. “I can’t wait to go dance when they’re here,” she said.

Morrison thinks the upcoming “Tails @Twilight” event on August 22 will be a big draw. Billed as “An Evening of Art, Tail-Wagging Fun and Puppy Kisses,” the event benefits local animal organizations. There will be a special happy hour menu offered by the venue’s restaurant, live music and a silent auction. It is bittersweet to already be thinking about the season closing, said Morrison.

Marrie Stone and Rina Palumbo offer an eight-week series on short-form writing at the Susi Q

Always wanted to write, but don’t want to commit to writing an entire novel or memoir? Or even a short story? Are you the type to keep things brief and pithy?

Published short story writers Marrie Stone and Rina Palumbo have just the class for you at the Susi Q – “Keep it Short: Writing stories in flash format.”

Click on photo for a larger image

Photo by Jeff Rovner

Marrie Stone

Stone, a podcaster who has interviewed literally hundreds of authors and is also an arts writer for Stu News Laguna, explains that flash is short-form writing of no more than 1,200 words that can be just as powerful as its longer relatives.

“The flash form challenges us to compress stories down to their essence to deliver an emotional punch to our readers,” Stone said. “We’ll talk about building rich worlds inside the walls of a literary doll’s house. The secret lies in how you paint the details and the magical power of suggestion.”

Click on photo for a larger image

Photo by Jeff Rovner

Rina Palumbo

Rina Palumbo, one of the founders of Third Street Writers, added her thoughts.

“Flash writing is a small container for big concepts. No other form of writing can show narrative’s true power to illuminate joy, sorrow and everything in between,” Palumbo noted.

Whether you want to create something from imagination or your life experience, this class will provide examples and guidance on forms and approaches to short-form writing.

“We’re going to help you generate story ideas, then guide you through critique and revision, and finally, give you advice on publication opportunities,” Stone added.

It’s going to be awesome.

“Keep It Short: Writing stories in flash format” will be offered as an eight-week series on Thursdays, Sept.12 through Oct. 31 from 9:30-11:30 a.m. for a fee of $160. The class is limited to eight participants, so act fast. LCAD collaborates with Group Y for the CreativityFlow Speaker Series

Ignite your mind and spark inspiration at the CreativityFlow speaker series, kicking off Wednesday, Sept. 11, at the Rivian South Coast Theater in Laguna Beach. This captivating monthly event series celebrates the groundbreaking ideas and creative solutions of today’s leading figures at the intersection of art, design and commerce. This dynamic event is a collaboration between Laguna College of Art + Design (LCAD) and Group Y, bringing you a front-row seat to the future of innovation.

Click on photo for a larger image

Courtesy of LCAD

CreativityFlow Speaker Series kicks off on September 11

Held in the heart of Laguna Beach, a city renowned for its vibrant art scene, CreativityFlow promises a unique convergence of inspiration and thought leadership. Distinguished speakers from diverse industries, including gaming, fashion, branding, fine art, culture, automotive, action sports and consumer packaged goods (CPG) will share their journeys and insights. These visionaries are reshaping their fields with innovative ideas and creative solutions.

The CreativityFlow series is a collaboration between Laguna College of Art + Design (LCAD), a prestigious art and design institution and Group Y, the leading network of youth culture professionals. Each month, attendees will have the opportunity to engage with these creative pioneers who are pushing boundaries and transforming industries.

Venue: Rivian South Coast Theater, Laguna Beach

Dates: September 11, October 2, November 6 and December 4

Tickets: Available now by clicking here (Individual and Series options)

Click on photo for a larger image

Courtesy of Rivian Forum

Rivian South Coast Theater

Confirmed Speakers:

September 11: ThankYouX, a renowned painter known for his geometric forms and digital blockchain-based artwork featured in top galleries and auction houses.

October 2: Nate Morley, founder of Works Collective, has developed brand identities for major global events like the FIFA World Cup, LA28 Olympics and iconic lifestyle brands. Roger Gastman, founder of Beyond The Streets, a renowned curator and historian, has played a pivotal role in elevating graffiti and street art as significant contemporary art forms.

November 6: Nikki Scoggins, VP of Creative Marketing at Blizzard Entertainment, has a passion for transforming ideas into impactful content for global gaming franchises.

Brian Takumi, VP of Brand Soul + Creative at Oakley, is driving brand vision and innovation through storytelling to shape its future while honoring its rich legacy.

December 4: Denise Cherry, VP of Experience Design at Rivian, leads a team that shapes every aspect of the customer journey, from brand building to product experience.

Andy Pearson, VP of Creative at Liquid Death, drives the bold creative vision for one of the fastest-growing non-alcoholic beverage brands, advancing its mission to promote health and sustainability through viral content and experiential events.

“We are thrilled to partner with Group Y for the CreativityFlow Speaker Series,” said Steve Brittan, president of Laguna College of Art + Design. “This event aligns perfectly with LCAD’s mission to foster creativity and innovation, providing a platform for visionary artists and designers to share their insights and inspire the next generation of creative minds.”

The CreativityFlow Speaker Series offers an unparalleled opportunity to:

–Immerse yourself in an atmosphere of creativity and innovation.

–Connect with like-minded individuals who share a passion for pushing boundaries.

–Gain insights from inspiring leaders who are shaping the future.

–This event is open to the public and a must-attend for creatives, entrepreneurs, marketers, artists and anyone passionate about the intersection of art, commerce and innovation.

Founded in 2006, Group Y is the original and leading collective of professionals focused on youth marketing, lifestyle and other progressive and expressive cultures. Their mission is to intersect influencers across industries and ignite ideas that inspire the current and next-generation leaders and decision makers. Leveraging events, outreach, content and consultation, Group Y takes the work out of networking and strengthens the areas where industries overlap.
